questiontext.text:
In 1984 the Rajneeshee cult poisoned 100s of people by contaminating the salad bars of restaurants with 

{1:SHORTANSWER:=Salmonella}
In 1992 Leonid Smirnov stole 1.5 kg of {1:SHORTANSWER:=Highly Enriched Uranium (HEU)} from Luch Scientific Production Association in Russia

hint.text: this material can be used in an improvised nuclear device

questiontext.text:
In contrast with nuclear materials there are a much 

{1:SHORTANSWER:=larger}
number of chemical substances and biological materials that are harmful to human health

hint.text: Consider relative size i.e. larger or smaller

questiontext.text: How many cases of HEU outside of regulatory control have there been in the last 20 years? Between {1:NUMERICAL:=5} and {1:NUMERICAL:=20}.
Why is it difficult to make predictions about the risk of CBRN terrorism?

answer.text: Diversity of CBRN weapon types and effects
Only limited studies carried out into the causes and consequences of terrorism

questiontext.text: Which of the following are chemical agents?
What did the 2001 Anthrax Letters attacks on the United States demonstrate?

answer.text: The difficulty in attributing attacks using biological agents
The significant disruptive and economic costs of an attack
The ease by which the effects of such an attack could be mitigated

questiontext.text: Why is security culture an essential component of any system designed to protect CBRN materials?

answer.text: The human factor within security systems has been shown to significantly influence their effectiveness

questiontext.text: Why do ‘insiders’ present arguably the greatest threat to CBRN facilities?

answer.text: They can legitimately bypass security measures designed to repel external adversaries
Historically the majority of thefts of CBRN materials have been carried out by insiders

questiontext.text: Which of the following are key components of the EU’s policy framework for combating WMD terrorism?
Which of the following chemical weapons did Aum Shinrikyo successfully produce and use in the Tokyo subway attacks?
Which groups might be labelled as ‘traditional terroists’? i.e. those that exhibit restraint, pursue limited goals and calibrate their actions to that end
Why might terrorist groups wish to develop and use CBRN weapons?

answer.text: Asymmetric’ properties i.e. disproportionate impact when compared to conventional explosives

questiontext.text: Why might terrorist groups restrain from developing and using CBRN weapons?
What would be the potential impact of an improvised nuclear device (IND) detonated in a city centre?

answer.text: Limited effects only in close proximity to the detonation site

questiontext.text: The Goiania accident in Brazil in 1987 illustrated that the use of a ‘dirty bomb’, would likely have the following effects
Which of the following motivations might drive terrorist groups to acquire CBRN weapons?
A ‘dirty bomb’ is best described by which of the following scenarios?

answer.text: Shielded radioactive material detonated via high explosive
Use of chemical weapons as a contaminants
Infection of a population with a biological agent

questiontext.text: Which of the following international initiatives related to CBRN security are legally binding?
What is meant by a graded approach to security management?

answer.text: Security measures are applied uniformly across all nuclear security facilities in all countries.
Security measures are based on the consequences of a successful attack and the likely threat.

questiontext.text: What is a ‘defence-in-depth’ approach to CBRN security?

answer.text: The use of multiple complementary security measures, recognising that no single security measures can defend against a determined adversary.
The use of a single security measure tailored to the threat posed by a particular adversary.

questiontext.text: Why is it difficult to make predictions about the risk of CBRN terrorism?

answer.text: Diversity of CBRN weapon types and effects
Only limited studies carried out into the causes and consequences of terrorism

questiontext.text: Which of the following chemical weapons did Aum Shinrikyo successfully produce and use in the Tokyo subway attacks?
Which groups might be labelled as ‘traditional terroists’? (i.e. those that exhibit restraint, pursue limited goals and calibrate their actions to that end)
Why might terrorist groups wish to develop and use CBRN weapons?

answer.text: ‘Asymmetric’ properties i.e. disproportionate impact when compared to conventional explosives

questiontext.text: Why might terrorist groups restrain from developing and using CBRN weapons?
What would be the potential impact of an improvised nuclear device (IND) detonated in a city centre?

answer.text: Limited effects only in close proximity to the detonation site

Which of the following are chemical agents?
What did the 2001 Anthrax Letters attacks on the United States demonstrate?

answer.text: The difficulty in attributing attacks using biological agents
The significant disruptive and economic costs of an attack
The ease by which the effects of such an attack could be mitigated

questiontext.text: Why is security culture an essential component of any system designed to protect CBRN materials?

answer.text: The human factor within security systems has been shown to significantly influence their effectiveness

questiontext.text: Why do ‘insiders’ present arguably the greatest threat to CBRN facilities?

answer.text: They can legitimately bypass security measures designed to repel external adversaries
Historically the majority of thefts of CBRN materials have been carried out by insiders

questiontext.text: Which of the following are key components of the EU’s policy framework for combating WMD terrorism?
How many known cases have there been where terrorists/external adversaries have broken into nuclear facilities and stolen nuclear material? (0, 1, 5 or more than 10)
In 1992 Leonid Smirnov stole 1.5 kg of __________ from Luch Scientific Production Association in Russia (HINT: this material can be used in an improvised nuclear device)

In contrast with nuclear materials there are a much ________ number of chemical substances and biological materials that are harmful to human health (HINT: Consider relative size i.e. Larger or smaller]
In 1984 the Rajneeshee cult poisoned 100s of people by contaminating the salad bars of restaurants with ________ (Hint: Name a biological agent)
